\documentclass{article}

\usepackage[backend=\jobname]{biblatex}

\usepackage{bibref,makeidx,nomencl}
\usepackage{sagetex}
\usepackage{pythontex}
\usepackage[acronym]{glossaries}

\makeglossaries

\newglossaryentry{baffles}{
  name=baffles,
  description={The blind spot behind a submarine which makes a good hidding spot
    for other submarines}
}

\newglossaryentry{zero}{
  name=absolute zero,
  description={The temperature at which entropy is minimized}
}

\newacronym{dc}{DC}{Direct Current}
\newacronym{rawq}{RAWQ}{Right Answer; Wrong Question}

\makeindex
\makenomenclature

\bibliography{BibTeXFile}{}

\begin{document}

Kilroy was here.

foo, wibble, wibble \cite{wibble}, \index{gronk}.

\section{Constants}

\nomenclature{$\alpha$}{Fine-structure constant (Sommerfeld's constant)}
\nomenclature{$\hbar$}{Dirac constant (reduced Planck constant)}

\begin{sageblock}
  f(x) = cos(x) * exp(x)
\end{sageblock}

The temperature in  the \gls{baffles} baffles is greater then \gls{zero} because
\acrlong{dc} can be abbreviated \acrshort{dc}.

\printnomenclature
\printglossary[type=\acronymtype]
\printglossary
\printbibliography
\printindex
